citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The tips of the ears of wolf hybrids “Mila” and “Jessie” are thickly crusted and darkly scabbed. Flies were seen landing on
their ears. The employees are putting the product Swat on the ears to help keep flies off, but the wolf hybrids do not
always cooperate. The fly strike has not been communicated to the attending veterinarian. Not communicating an ongoing
health problem with the wolf hybrids can cause unnecessary pain and suffering. A mechanism of direct and frequent
communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being
is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by October 17, 2025.

The official identification of the wolf hybrids could not be ascertained at the time of the inspection. It was thought that they
were identified with the use of microchips, but the required microchip scanner could not be located by the facility
representative. Proper identification allows for the tracking of animals into, throughout, and out of the facility as well as
allows for the official identification of individual animals within the facility. All animals must be officially identified by either
tags (with required information), tattoos (approved by the Administrator), record book (as outlined in 2.50(c)(2)), or
microchips (with functioning scanner present at the facility). To be corrected by September 29, 2025,

The facility is not maintaining records that fully disclose all the required information by the animal welfare act. The name,
addresses, vehicle license number and state, driver's license number, the description or each wolf hybrid, and the method
of transportation are partially or completely missing for wolf hybrids that were acquired or left the facility. Complete and
accurate records must be kept in order to ensure that each animal's identity can be known with certainty and to facilitate
tracking/tracing of animals.
Each dealer, other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and each exhibitor shall
make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning each
dog or cat purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her
control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The records shall
include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control. To be corrected by
October 17, 2025.

The facility is not keeping a Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on hand form (APHIS form 7005) or a Record of
Disposition of dogs and cats form (APHIS form 7006) for the wolf hybrids at the facility. The acquisition and disposition
records are instead being kept on documents they have created. They do not have a variance in place that allows them to
use other forms. Failure to use APHIS form 7005 and 7006 does not allow for proper traceability and management of
regulated animals at a facility.
Each dealer and exhibitor shall use the Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS Form 7005) and Record
of Disposition of Dogs and Cats (APHIS Form 7006) to make, keep, and maintain the information required by paragraph
(a)(1) of this section. Provided, that if a dealer or exhibitor who uses a computerized recordkeeping system believes that
APHIS Form 7005 and APHIS Form 7006 are unsuitable for him or her to make, keep, and maintain the information
required by paragraph (a)(1) of this section, the dealer or exhibitor may request a variance from the requirement to use
APHIS Form 7005 and APHIS form 7006. Correct by ensuring all required information is fully and correctly documented
on an APHIS Form 7005 and 7006, or by obtaining a variance. To be corrected by October 17, 2025.

The buried wire in several enclosures has been exposed by the digging of the wolf hybrids in these enclosures. This
digging has resulted in holes through the wire into the ground where a wolf hybrid’s leg could fall through and cause
injury.
In some enclosures, the chicken wire fencing that has been fastened to the welded wire fencing has been torn loose
resulting in sharp points protruding into the enclosures.
There is a corrugated metal panel laying on top of the ground that has exposed sharp edges in one enclosure housing
two wolf hybrids.
An enclosure containing two wolf hybrids has two igloo-type shelters that are chewed up around the entrances of the
shelters.
Holes through buried wire, sharp points, and sharp metal edges could cause injury to the wolf hybrids. Housing facilities
for wolf hybrids must be kept in good repair to protect them from injury.

An enclosure containing 4 wolf hybrids has a single shelter that is not large enough for the four wolf hybrids to be able to
sit, stand, and lie in a normal manner at the same time. Also, many of the enclosures do not provide adequate shade for
all the wolf hybrids present in the enclosures. Wolf hybrids are not adequately protected from the elements of the weather
if not provided large enough shelters for all wolf hybrids present in the enclosure to be able to access it all at the same
time. Lack of adequate shade from the direct rays of the sun can cause discomfort and could have an impact on the
health and well-being of the wolf hybrids. All enclosures must be provided with large enough shelters that are accessible
to each wolf hybrid and that allow them to sit, stand, lie down and turn about freely at the same time. All outdoor
enclosures must be provided with adequate shade structures in addition to the shelter structures to provide enough shade
to contain all the wolf hybrids at one time. The licensee must ensure that shade is provided and be large enough to
contain all the dogs at one time and protect them from the direct rays of the sun. To be corrected by October 17, 2025.

The wolf hybrid wooden dog houses are not impervious to moisture, some have holes in the ceiling, walls, and/or floors,
some of the plastic pools are severely chewed, some of the wood around the dog house entrances are severely chewed,
and the raised dog beds have torn fabric. Frayed and chewed surfaces cannot be cleaned and sanitized and could cause
infection if bacteria or viruses are harbored in the material. Surfaces permeable to moisture cannot be properly cleaned
and/or sanitized as contaminated material can penetrate into the surfaces. Having surfaces in contact with the animals
that cannot be properly cleaned and sanitized can expose the wolf hybrids to unnecessary disease hazards. Building
surfaces in contact with animals in outdoor housing facilities must be impervious to moisture. All surfaces must be
maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of outdoor housing facilities – including houses, dens, etc. – that cannot be
readily cleaned and sanitized must be replaced when worn or soiled. To be corrected by October 17, 2025.

The only water receptacle in one enclosure housing two wolf hybrids is void of water and the bottom of this bucket is dry.
Lack of water can have a negative impact on the health of wolf hybrids. Water must be continuously available to the wolf
hybrids. The water receptacle was filled with water at the time of the inspection. Corrected during the inspection on
September 15, 2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The facility is not sanitizing the wolf hybrid primary enclosures. Proper sanitization of primary enclosures is important for
reducing disease hazards such as potential odors, dirt, debris, and bodily waste, which can lead to an increased risk of
illness or disease. Used primary enclosures must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks using one of the methods
prescribed in paragraph (b)(3) of this section, and more necessary to prevent accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste,
excreta, and other disease hazards. To be corrected by October 6, 2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There is a large pile of trash including soiled food boxes and feces located in and around the food prep area that is
drawing an excessive number of flies. Flies can carry diseases and contribute to illness, fly strike, and infection of the wolf
hybrids. An effective program for the control of insects, external parasites affecting dogs that are pests, must be
established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests
in animal areas. To be corrected by October 17, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
KENDALL LUNDY, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
